questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a content of the cubital fossa?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Ulnar nerve Explanation: Cubital Fossa: Triangular space present in front of distal humerus and elbow joint. Boundaries: Medially Lateral border of pronator teres Laterally Medial border of brachioradialis Apex Point of convergence of medial and lateral boundaries Base Imaginary line connecting the medial and lateral epicondyles of humerus. Roof Formed by deep fascia and reinforced by bicipital aponeurosis.The deep fascia is continuity of brachial and antebrachial fascia. Floor Lower portion of brachialis forms the floor of the upper part of the fossa; the supinator muscle forms the floor of the lower part of the fossa. Contents of cubital fossa: Median nerve: Lies medial to the brachial artery in the fossa and is anterior to brachioradialis and posterior to bicipital aponeurosis. Radial nerve: Enters the cubital region by passing forwards in interval between the brachialis and brachioradialis and then divides into superficial branch and deep branch (posterior interosseous nerve). Brachial artery: Centrally placed in fossa and divides into radial and ulnar arteries with immediate anterior relation is bicipital aponeurosis. Tendon of the biceps brachii and bicipital aponeurosis Contents of cubital fossa from medial to lateral: (Mnemonic: MBBS) Median nerve Brachial artery Biceps brachii tendon Superficial branch of radial nerve Reference: Inderbir Singh's Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-1, 6th Edition, Page 170,171

questions.question: Which of the following is a unique feature of the clavicle compared to other bones in the body?

options.A: It ossifies from both membranous and cartilaginous origins.
options.B: It articulates directly with the scapula without an intervening joint cavity.
options.C: It is the only bone in the body that does not have a medullary cavity.
options.D: It is entirely covered by the periosteum, unlike other bones.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It ossifies from both membranous and cartilaginous origins Explanation: The clavicle is unique among bones in the human body due to its dual ossification process: Intramembranous Ossification : The medial and lateral parts of the clavicle develop through intramembranous ossification. This process is typical for flat bones like the skull. Endochondral Ossification : The sternal end of the clavicle ossifies through endochondral ossification, which involves a cartilage template being replaced by bone. This process is more common for long bones like the femur and humerus. Features of the Clavicle: Horizontally placed long bone (unique among long bones). Two primary centers of ossification develop during intrauterine life to form the shaft (most long bones have only one primary center). One secondary ossification center Subcutaneous throughout and easily palpable. Lacks a medullary cavity , unlike most long bones. Parts of the Clavicle: Medial 2/3 : Anterior convexity. Lateral 1/3 : Anterior concavity. Junction of these segments is prone to fractures. Muscle Attachments: Medial 2/3 (Anterior) : Origin of Pectoralis Major . Lateral 1/3 (Anterior) : Origin of Deltoid . Lateral 1/3 (Posterior) : Insertion of Trapezius . The clavicle articulates with the scapula at the acromioclavicular joint , which does have a joint cavity. (Option B) While it is true that the clavicle lacks a medullary cavity, it is not the only bone with this feature (Flat bones like the sternum and skull bones). (Option C) All bones in the body are covered by periosteum except at articular surfaces. This characteristic is not unique to the clavicle. (Option D) Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 6

questions.question: Which of the following is not a content in the 4th compartment of extensor retinaculum?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Extensor pollicis brevis Explanation: Extensor pollicis brevis is in the 1st compartment of the extensor retinaculum. Extensor Retinaculum - Thickened deep fascia on the back of the wrist Compartment of Extensor Retinaculum Structure(s) I Abductor pollicis longus Extensor pollicis brevis II Extensor carpi radialis longus Extensor carpi radialis brevis III Extensor pollicis longus IV Extensor digitorum Extensor indicis Posterior interosseous nerve Anterior interosseous artery V Extensor digiti minimi VI Extensor carpi ulnaris Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 145-146

questions.question: After a fall from a height with undue arm abduction, the patient presented as shown. Mark the wrong statement about this condition.

options.B: Complete clawing of hand is seen
options.C: Associated horner syndrome can be seen
options.D: Due to injury to lower trunk of brachial plexus

questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) C7,C8 & T1 are affected Explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klumpke’s paralysis secondary to fall with abduction of arm causing injury to C8 and T1 nerve roots resulting in complete clawing of hand . Erb’s Paralysis & Klumpke’s Paralysis: Feature Erb’s Paralysis Klumpke’s Paralysis Site of Injury Upper trunk of the brachial plexus (Erb’s point) Lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Option D) Causes of Injury Undue separation of head from the shoulder Birth injury/difficult childbirth During anesthesia Undue abduction of the arm Birth injury Nerve Roots Involved Mainly C5, partly C6 Mainly T1, partly C8 (Option A) Muscles Paralyzed Biceps brachii Deltoid Brachialis Brachioradialis Partly supraspinatus, infraspinatus, supinator Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8) Deformity and Position Arm: Hangs by the side, adducted and medially rotated Forearm: Extended and pronated (Waiter’s tip position) Also known as Policeman tip deformity Complete clawing of hand due to hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. (Option B) Additional Features Sensory loss over lower deltoid. Bird winging effect of scapula. Horner’s syndrome (Option C) if T1 is injured. Vasomotor and trophic changes Cutaneous anesthesia along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the carrying angle of the elbow is correct? flexed.

options.A: The carrying angle is formed by the angle between the humerus and the ulna when the elbow is
options.B: The carrying angle disappears during full flexion and pronation of the forearm.
options.C: The carrying angle is greater in males, usually more than 15°.
options.D: The carrying angle increases as the arm moves from full flexion to extension.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The carrying angle disappears during full flexion and pronation of the forearm. arm is fully extended. This angle, typically 13° , is due to the medially and downwardly directed transverse axis of the elbow joint. The factors that contribute to this angle include: Medial flange of the trochlea being 6 mm deeper than the lateral flange. Oblique placement of the superior articular surface of the coronoid process of the ulna. The carrying angle disappears during full flexion and pronation of the forearm, with the forearm aligning with the arm in the mid-prone position. This allows better precision in hand control. The angle is typically 10°–15° in males and greater than 15° in females Cubitus valgus is characterized by an increased carrying angle, causing the forearm to deviate outward , while cubitus varus involves a decreased carrying angle, causing the forearm to angle inward. Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 166

questions.question: Which of the following structures can be palpated in the infraclavicular fossa ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Coracoid process Explanation: The infraclavicular fossa , also known as the deltopectoral triangle , is a triangular depression located below the junction of the lateral and middle thirds of the clavicle. It is defined by the following boundaries: Medially : The pectoralis major muscle. Laterally : The anterior fibers of the deltoid muscle. Superiorly : The clavicle . The tip of the coracoid process of the scapula lies approximately 2–3 cm below the clavicle and is overlapped by the anterior fibers of the deltoid. It can be felt during deep palpation just lateral to the infraclavicular fossa , which helps in locating important structures like the brachial plexus and subclavian artery in clinical assessments. This area is clinically significant for procedures such as brachial plexus block and the assessment of vascular structures like the subclavian artery . Reference: BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 1, 8th Edition, Page 37

questions.question: Identify the correctly marked attachments of the Upper end of the Humerus.

options.A: A- Supraspinatus; B- Infraspinatus; D- Pectoralis major
options.B: A- Teres minor; B- Infraspinatus; D- Subscapularis
options.C: C- Pectoralis major; D- Supraspinatus; E- Subscapularis
options.D: B- Infraspinatus; C- Pectoralis major; D- Supraspinatus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) A- Supraspinatus; B- Infraspinatus; D- Pectoralis major Explanation: Upper end of Humerus: Head: The smooth, rounded head forms one-third of a sphere, covered with articular hyaline cartilage. Anatomical Neck: This constriction at the margins of the rounded head provides attachment to the capsular ligament of the shoulder joint , except at the superior region where the capsule is deficient for the tendon of the long head of the biceps brachii. Surgical Neck: A short constriction below the tubercles and epiphyseal line, where fractures are common. It is in close proximity to the axillary nerve and posterior and anterior circumflex humeral vessels. Greater Tubercle: The most lateral part of the upper end, with three flattened facets: Upper facet: Attachment for supraspinatus. Middle facet: Attachment for infraspinatus. Lower facet: Attachment for teres minor. Mnemonic : "SIT" Lesser Tubercle: A small elevation on the front of the upper end, just above the surgical neck, providing attachment for the subscapularis muscle . Intertubercular Sulcus (Bicipital Groove): A groove between the tubercles that contains: Long head of biceps (enclosed in a synovial sheath). Ascending branch of anterior circumflex humeral artery. It provides attachment to three muscles: Pectoralis major (lateral lip) . Teres major (medial lip). Latissimus dorsi (floor). Mnemonic : "Lady between 2 Majors" (Latissimus dorsi between Pectoralis major and Teres major).

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes the attachments on the coracoid process?

options.A: The short head of biceps brachii and coracobrachialis insert onto its medial border.
options.B: The conoid ligament attaches to the tip of the coracoid process.
options.C: The pectoralis minor muscle inserts onto the medial border of the upper surface.
options.D: The coracoacromial ligament attaches to the superior ridge of the coracoid process.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The pectoralis minor muscle inserts onto the medial border of the upper surface. coracobrachialis arise from the tip via a common tendon. (Option A) Pectoralis minor inserts on the medial border of the upper surface . Ligament Attachments : Coracoacromial ligament attaches to the lateral border . (Option D) Conoid ligament (part of coracoclavicular) attaches to the knuckle . (Option B) Trapezoid ligament (part of coracoclavicular) attaches to the ridge on the superior aspect. Coracohumeral ligament attaches at the root , near the glenoid cavity. Reference: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-1, 2nd Edition, Page 18

questions.question: Which of the following bones is not directly involved in the radiocarpal (wrist) joint?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pisiform Explanation: Pisiform is a sesamoid bone located in the proximal row of the carpal bones but does not participate directly in the radiocarpal articulation. Wrist joint Synovial ellipsoidal (condyloid) joint allowing flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction. Articulating Bones The wrist joint involves the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones (scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum). The ulna is not directly involved in the wrist joint but is adjacent to it, separated by an articular disc (the triangular fibrocartilage). Carpal Bones Involved Scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum are directly involved in the articulation with the radius. The pisiform is not involved in the wrist joint. Joint Capsule A fibrous joint capsule encloses the wrist joint, which is lined by a synovial membrane that produces synovial fluid for lubrication. Ligaments Palmar radiocarpal ligament Dorsal radiocarpal ligament Ulnar collateral ligament Radial collateral ligament Movements Flexion Extension Radial deviation (abduction) Ulnar deviation (adduction) Circumduction Blood Supply The wrist joint is supplied by branches of the radial and ulnar arteries. Nerve Supply Median nerve Ulnar nerve Radial nerve Clinical Relevance Common conditions affecting the wrist joint include wrist fractures (especially of the scaphoid and radius), carpal tunnel syndrome, and arthritis. Reference: Wrist joint

questions.question: The muscles in the posterior aspect of the forearm are given below. Which among these is involved in the extension of the elbow joint?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Anconeus Explanation: Posterior forearm muscles Origin Insertion Nerve Supply Actions Anconeus (Option A) Lateral epicondyle of humerus Lateral surface of olecranon process of ulna Radial nerve Extends elbow joint Brachioradialis (Option B) Upper two-thirds of lateral supracondylar ridge of humerus Base of styloid process of radius Radial nerve Flexes forearm at elbow ; rotates forearm to midprone position Extensor carpi radialis longus Lower one-third of lateral supracondylar ridge of humerus Posterior surface of base of second metacarpal bone Radial nerve Extends and abducts hand at wrist Extensor carpi radialis brevis Lateral epicondyle of humerus Posterior surface of base of third metacarpal Deep branch of radial nerve Extends and abducts hand at wrist Extensor digitorum (Option D) Lateral epicondyle of humerus Bases of middle phalanges of the 2nd–5th digits Deep branch of radial nerve Extends fingers of hand Extensor digiti minimi Lateral epicondyle of humerus Extensor expansion of little finger Deep branch of radial nerve Extends metacarpophalangeal joint of little finger Extensor carpi ulnaris Lateral epicondyle of humerus Base of fifth metacarpal bone Deep branch of radial nerve Extends and adducts hand at wrist Supinator (Option C) Lateral epicondyle of humerus, annular ligament of superior radioulnar joint, supinator crest of ulna Neck and upper third of radius Deep branch of radial nerve Supinates forearm when elbow is extended Abductor pollicis longus Posterior surface of shafts of radius and ulna Base of first metacarpal bone Deep branch of radial nerve Abducts and extends thumb Extensor pollicis brevis Posterior surface of shaft of radius Base of proximal phalanx of thumb Deep branch of radial nerve Extends metacarpophalangeal joint of thumb Extensor pollicis longus Posterior surface of shaft of ulna Base of distal phalanx of thumb Deep branch of radial nerve Extends distal phalanx of thumb Extensor indicis Posterior surface of shaft of ulna Extensor expansion of index finger Deep branch of radial nerve Extends metacarpophalangeal joint of index finger

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman falls off her bicycle and lands on her outstretched hand. She presents with pain and swelling over the lateral aspect of her wrist. On examination, there is tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. Which underlying bone is most likely fractured?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Scaphoid Explanation: Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture , as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Anatomical snuff box/Radial fossa: Triangular hollow visible on the lateral aspect of the wrist when the thumb is fully extended. Boundaries: Anterolateral: Extensor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis longus Posteromedial: Extensor pollicis longus Roof: Dorsal cutaneous branch of radial nerve: Found in the skin and subcutaneous tissue of anatomical snuff box. Cephalic vein: Arises from dorsal venous network of hand and crosses anatomical snuff box to travel to the anterolateral aspect of forearm. Contents: Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box. Reference: Inderbir Singh's Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-1, 6th Edition, Page 197

questions.question: Choose the correct statement regarding the muscle being tested in the given image. by ulnar nerve

options.B: Muscles of 1st and 2nd digits are supplied by median nerve and 3rd & 4th digit muscles are supplied
options.C: Causes flexion of interphalangeal and extension of metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Absent in thumb Explanation: Test shown in the image is done to test Dorsal interossei , where the patient is asked to abduct the fingers against resistance. Dorsal interossei are bipennate muscles , supplied by deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Palmar Interossei Dorsal Interossei Arrangement Unipennate (Option A) Bipennate Action Adduction of fingers (PAd) Abduction of fingers (DAb) Nerve supply Deep branch of ulnar nerve Absent in Middle finger Thumb and little finger (Option D) Number of muscles 4 in no. 4 in no. (middle finger has 2) Clinical test Card test (adduction of digits) Egawa test (abduction of digits) Lumbricals: Action Flexion at metacarpophalangeal joint and extension at interphalangeal joint (Option C) Nerve supply 1st & 2nd: Median nerve (Option B) 3rd & 4th: Ulnar nerve Arrangement 1st & 2nd: Unipennate 3rd & 4th: Bipennate Other points Also known as Linker muscles as they connect the flexor compartment of muscles with the extensor muscles. Insertion: via extensor expansion into dorsum of base of distal phalanx

questions.question: Given below is an image showing insertion of a muscle (marked in red) on the palmar aspect of the hand. Identify the correct pair of muscles and its corresponding nerve supply.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Opponens digiti minimi - ulnar nerve Explanation: Muscle shown in the image above is Opponens digiti minimi , present in hypothenar compartment. All the hypothenar muscles are innervated by deep branch of the Ulnar nerve. Muscles of Hypothenar Eminence: Muscle Attachments Nerve supply Action Abductor digiti minimi Origin: Pisiform Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of little finger Deep branch of Ulnar nerve Abduction of little finger Flexor digiti minimi Origin: Flexor retinaculum Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of little finger Flexion of little finger Opponens digiti minimi Origin: Flexor retinaculum Insertion: Medial border of fifth metacarpal bone Pulls 5th metacarpal forward

questions.question: Patient following RTA was brought to ED, where he was told that his ulnar nerve is injured. Which of the following muscles would be affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 4 Explanation: Image shows the thenar muscles of the hand . Only thenar muscle of the hand supplied by the ulnar nerve is Adductor pollicis (Option A) , which would be affected in this scenario. Rest of the muscles of thenar eminence are supplied by the median nerve. Muscles of Thenar Eminence: Muscle Attachments Nerve supply Action Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C) Origin: Scaphoid tubercle, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb Median nerve Abduction of thumb Flexor pollicis brevis (Option B) Origin: Capitate, crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb Median nerve Flexion of metacarpo-phalangeal joint of thumb Opponens pollicis (Option D) Origin: crest of Trapezium and flexor retinaculum Insertion: Lateral half of palmar surface of the shaft of thumb metacarpal Median nerve Opposition of thumb towards fingers Adductor pollicis (Option A) Origin: Oblique head- base of 2nd-3rd metacarpal ; transverse head- shaft of 3rd metacarpal Insertion: Base of proximal phalanx of thumb (medial aspect) Ulnar nerve Adduction of thumb Clinical Tests: Abductor pollicis brevis: Pen test is done. Patient is asked to abduct the thumb. Patients will be unable to do so in case of median nerve injury Adductor pollicis: Froment's sign , also known as the book test , evaluates the function of the adductor pollicis muscle (supplied by ulnar nerve). When a patient is asked to firmly grip a book between the thumbs and

questions.question: All are true about the shown muscle except.

options.B: Causes flexion of arm at shoulder joint

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Paralyzed in Erb’s palsy Explanation: Shown muscle is Coracobrachialis , which may not be paralyzed in Erb’s palsy as all other options are correct. Fig: Coracobrachialis muscle Coracobrachialis: Origin: Medial coracoid process Insertion: Medial aspect of middle humerus Nerve supply: Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7) Action: Flexion (+adduction) of arm at shoulder joint May not be paralyzed in Erb’s palsy, as in case of Erb’s palsy: C5,C6 are compromised but C7 remains unaffected and hence Coracobrachialis is not paralyzed . (Option C) Muscles of Arm: Muscle Attachments Nerve supply Action Biceps brachii Origin: Short head- Coracoid process ; Long head- Supragelnoid tubercle Insertion: Radial tuberosity Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C6) Flexion and supination of forearm Brachialis Origin: anterior humerus Insertion: coronoid process & ulnar tuberosity Motor: Musculocutaneous nerve Proprioceptive: Radial nerve Flexion of forearm Coraco- brachialis Origin: medial coracoid process (Option D) Insertion: medial aspect of middle humerus Musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7) (Option A) Flexion of arm (Option B)

questions.question: In which sequence do the following carpal bones typically ossify: capitate, pisiform, scaphoid? → Scaphoid → Pisiform → Capitate → Scaphoid → Capitate → Pisiform → Pisiform → Scaphoid
questions.explanation: → Scaphoid → Pisiform Correct Answer: A) Capitate → Scaphoid → Pisiform Explanation: Carpal bones are 8 short bones arranged in 2 rows, each with 4 bones in the region of the wrist. From lateral to medial, bones of the proximal row are the scaphoid, lunate, triquetral, and pisiform, and those of the distal row are the trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, and hamate. Carpal Bones Ossification Age Capitate (First one to ossify) 1-3 Months Hamate 2-4 Months Triquetrum During 3rd year of life Lunate During 4th year of life Scaphoid During 5th year of life Trapezium During 6th year of life Trapezoid During 6-7th year of life Pisiform (Last one to ossify) During 9-12th year of life Reference: Carpal bones

questions.question: Which of the following muscles is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Flexor digitorum profundus Explanation: The flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) is responsible for flexing the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the 2nd to 5th fingers. The muscles of the anterior compartment of forearm are the flexor-pronator muscles and arranged in 3 layers: Superficial layer: Pronator teres Flexor carpi radialis Flexor carpi ulnaris Palmaris longus Intermediate layer: Flexor digitorum superficialis Deep layer: 1. Flexor digitorum profundus: Origin Proximal three-quarters of the anterior and medial surfaces of the ulna and the interosseous membrane. Insertion Bases of the distal phalanges of the 2nd to 5th digits. Action Flexes the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints of the 2nd to 5th fingers and flexion of wrist. Nerve Supply Medial part by ulnar nerve and lateral part by median nerve (C8, T1) 2. Flexor Pollicis Longus: Origin Anterior surface of the radius and adjacent interosseous membrane. Insertion Base of the distal phalanx of the thumb. Action Flexion of phalanges of thumb Nerve Supply Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch) (C8, T1). 3. Pronator Quadratus: Origin Distal one-quarter of the anterior surface of the ulna. Insertion Distal one-quarter of the anterior surface of the radius. Action Pronation of the forearm (pulls the radius over the ulna). Nerve Supply Median nerve (anterior interosseous branch) (C8, T1). Reference: Inderbir Singh's Textbook of Anatomy, Volume-1, 6th Edition, Page 176,177,179,180

questions.question: A 35-year-old carpenter presents with pain and weakness in his right forearm after repetitive hammering. On examination, you note tenderness over the medial epicondyle and weakness in wrist flexion. There is no sensory loss. Based on these findings, which muscle is not likely involved?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Flexor pollicis longus Explanation: Flexor pollicis longus is a deep muscle of the anterior compartment of forearm which helps in flexion of distal phalanges of the thumb and no action in flexion of wrist. The muscles of the anterior compartment of forearm are the flexor-pronator muscles and arranged in 3 layers: Superficial layer: Pronator teres Flexor carpi radialis Flexor carpi ulnaris Palmaris longus Intermediate layer: Flexor digitorum superficialis Deep layer: Flexor digitorum profundus Flexor pollicis longus Pronator quadratus Superficial muscles of anterior compartment of forearm consists of 5 muscles: 1. Pronator teres: Origin Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon) Ulnar head - Coronoid process of the ulna Insertion Lateral surface of the midshaft of the radius. Action Pronates the forearm and weak flexor of elbow. Nerve Supply Median nerve (C6, C7). 2. Flexor Carpi Radialis (FCR): Origin Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon). Insertion Base of the second and third metacarpal bones. Action Flexes and abducts the wrist (radial deviation). Nerve Supply Median nerve (C6, C7). 3. Palmaris Longus: Origin Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon). Insertion Flexor retinaculum and palmar aponeurosis. Action Flexion of hand at wrist makes palmar aponeurosis tense. Nerve Supply Median nerve (C7, C8). 4. Flexor Carpi Ulnaris: Origin Humeral head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus (via the common flexor tendon) Ulnar head- Olecranon and posterior border of the ulna. Insertion Pisiform, hook of hamate, and base of the fifth metacarpal. Action Flexes and adducts the wrist Nerve Supply Ulnar nerve (C7, C8). 5. Flexor Digitorum Superficialis: Origin Humeroulnar head- Medial epicondyle of the humerus and coronoid process of the ulna Radial head- Oblique line of the radius Insertion Middle phalanges of the 2nd to 5th digits. Action Flexion of middle and proximal phalanges of digits. Nerve Supply Median nerve (C7, C8, T1)
